Hofstetter 2014 | synonyms = ''Agaricus palustris'' [[Charles Horton Peck|Peck]] 1872
''Mycena palustris'' ([[Charles Horton Peck|Peck]]) [[Pier Andrea Saccardo|Sacc.]] 1887
''Tephrophana palustris'' ([[Charles Horton Peck|Peck]]) [[Robert Kühner|Kühner]] 1938

''Bryophyllum palustre'' ([[Charles Horton Peck|Peck]]) Vizzini 2014 }} {{ mycomorphbox | name = ''Sphagnurus paluster'' | whichGills = adnate | whichGills2 = sinuate | capShape = conical | capShape2 = flat | hymeniumType = gills | stipeCharacter = bare | ecologicalType = parasitic | sporePrintColor = white | howEdible = unknown }} {{Portal|Fungi}} '''''Sphagnurus paluster''''' is a species of [[fungus]] in the family [[Lyophyllaceae]] which [[parasitism|parasitizes]] [[Sphagnum]] moss. It was first described by [[Charles Horton Peck]] in 1872. It is commonly called the '''Sphagnum Greyling''' due to it being found in peat bogs and to its cap turning grey as it ages and dries. ==Description== ''Sphagnurus paluster'' can be white pruinose when young and does not stain or bruise when crushed. Its flesh is thin, soft, and watery. The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is {{convert|1|to|3|cm|in|sigfig=2}} in diameter, starting as conical or bell shape when young, expanding flat with a distinct umbo when older. It is smooth, striate, and hygrophanous; usually an olive-brown when moist, drying to a pale grey color. The white to grey [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are adnate or with a slight tooth. Subgills are often present creating a close to subdistant spacing. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|2|to|10|cm|in|sigfig=2}} long and {{convert|1|to|5|mm|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter, equal and hollow. The coloring is usually lighter than the cap, being grey-brown or grey. The white to cream colored [[basidiospore|spore]]s are 5.5 to 8.5 µm x 4 to 4.5 µm, elliptical, and smooth.{{cite web |last=Gibson |first=Ian |url=http://www.svims.ca/council/Lyophy.htm |title=LYOPHYLLUM and Allies in the Pacific Northwest |publisher=Pacific Northwest Key Council |accessdate=17 May 2011 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5826~gid~~source~gallerydefault.asp |title= Lyophyllum palustre |publisher=Rogers Mushrooms |accessdate=15 May 2011 }} ==Distribution and habitat== Grows in spring to early summer in cool northern climates that support [[Sphagnum]]. Found single to [[wikt:gregarious|gregarious]], often growing in bogs or ditches always on ''[[Sphagnum]]''. ==Edibility== Unknown. Odor and taste is farinaceous. ==Parasitism== ''Sphagnurus paluster'' parasitizes living ''[[Sphagnum]]'' mosses by forming penetration pegs through hyphae pressure. At the tips of these pegs pectinases are produced to digest the lamella between leaf cells which facilitates entry into both hyaline and chlorophyllous cells. The result is a deterioration of the protoplast and necrosis of the cells. The rate of parasitic expansion is theorized to be related to the amount of available nitrogen in the host and parasite mediums.Davey ML, Currah RS: Interactions between mosses (Bryophyta) and fungi. Can J Bot 2006, 84:1509-1519 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Tephrocybe palustris}} *[http://www.commanster.eu/commanster/Mushrooms/Agaric/SpAgaric/Tephrocybe.palustris.html ''T. palustris'' at Commanster.eu] *[http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5826~gid~~source~gallerydefault.asp ''L. palustre'' at Rogers Mushrooms] {{Taxonbar|from=Q4355424}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sphagnurus paluster}} [[Category:Lyophyllaceae]] [[Category:Parasitic fungi]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of Asia]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1872]]
